intro: Quiina magallano-gomesii, commonly known as the Magallanes quiina, is a flowering plant native to South America, specifically found in parts of Chile and Argentina. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible seeds. The plant is characterized by its upright growth habit, with slender stems and small, clustered flowers that bloom in early spring. Its leaves are typically arrow-shaped and have a rough, textured surface, which helps it thrive in arid environments. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and specialized species within its native range.
